awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Structure Based Machine Learning Aided Protein Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project spans chemical manufacturing, pharmaceutical development, and agricultural biotechnology. This technology helps protein engineers take a candidate protein and make it more robust to chemical or environmental perturbations. In one application, this technology could be used to extend the half-life of pharmaceutical candidates during development. In another application, it could enable substituting toxic and wasteful chemistries with suitable enzymatic chemistries. These algorithms may help drive new green chemistries presently inaccessible because although the necessary enzymes can perform a desired catalysis, they cannot stay folded long enough for commercial use.  In a third application, the technology can help improve the shelf life of these critical drugs, thereby expanding the population they might benefit.

This I-Corps project leverages machine learning to accelerate protein engineering. Convolutional neural networks have recently become the preferred artificial intelligence (AI) solution to a number of computer vision challenges, yet their biological applications remain scarce. Proteins, strings of folded amino acids that drive most biological processes, are exponentially being crystallized to solve their three-dimensional structure. This project combines these two resources by training a 3D convolutional neural network that characterizes chemical environments unique to each of the 20 amino acids. The same neural network can then predict the amino acid best fitting a given environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
With the support of the NSF national I-corps program, our team conducted market research in seven cities throughout the US. Team #1620 'AI Protein Solutions' conducted 110 interviews during the seven week intensive training as the Summer 2019 Chicago cohort. These interviews were conducted with individuals and representatives of comanies sampled across the ecosystem of protein engineering. Of these 110 interviews, 93 were conducted in person while the remaining 17 were conducted via teleconferencing or video call. Through this customer discovery process, we identified several key partners and potential consumers of the software service which aims to improve and reduce the risk of failure when designing new and more stable proteins. These organizations were diverse, ranging from pharmaceutical manufacturers, to drug discovery, to metabolic engineering.

 

During this process, the key value proposition offered by our approach was clarified. While we initially hypothesized that consumers of our service needed to de-risk product development, we later learned that our software offered more value than risk mitigation. The process we enable is time intensive, contingent on a PhD level expert guiding it, and sometimes fails. Each of these three features (duration, domain expertise, and risk) can be improved by our software service.

 

Furthermore, the product that potential customers may buy was also clarified. Initially, the team thought customers would be interested in licensing a software package to test their own hypotheses. As it turns out, many potential users of our software are skeptical of their own ability to work with bioinformatics tools. These users are happy to pay a company to run proprietary software and deliver the results of a software analysis. Now, we have pivoted to a service model.

 

These insights have prepared the graduate student Co-Entrepreneurial leads to better tailor their software for the demands of potential users in synthetic biology, protein engineering, and drug development. The tenants of the Lean Startup have further refined the Entrepreneurial leads? understanding of the core components founding a successful startup. This foundational understanding of customer value, channels of communication, mechanisms to discover new customers, partners that will enable company growth, competition, and monetization (among others) will serve as a scaffold on which the two Entrepreneurial leads will further mature the commercial applications of their AI Protein Technology. As a result of the relationships developed and market research conducted in the I-Corps program a company, Aperiam Bio, was formed. The outcome of this NSF I-Corps customer discovery process provided the team with a better understanding of the real world requirements of technology startups and showed them several examples of successful startups to emulate.

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2020
Modified by: Andrew D Ellington
